header.title: Invocating by Magic Crystals and Mirrors

central_thesis: The book presents Frederick Hockley's practical system for invoking and communicating with spirits, including Guardian Spirits and high-order angels, through scrying using consecrated crystals and mirrors, drawing on traditions like the Urim and Thummim, and contrasting it with other divination methods and the broader Victorian Spiritualist movement. It emphasizes a structured, ritualistic approach for safe and effective spirit interaction, culminating in profound spiritual knowledge.

structure_content.summary: This section provides essential historical and social context for crystal gazing (crystallomancy) in Victorian Spiritualism, situating Hockley's unique work among key practitioners like John Dee, Christopher Cooke, and contemporary Spiritualists. It highlights Hockley's background, his meticulous approach to creating esoteric manuscripts, and his engagement with the London Dialectical Society. The introduction details the significance of this particular manuscript, which was crafted as a personal gift for Barbara Honywood, and contextualizes Hockley's methods within the broader magical currents of his time, noting his blending of traditional angelic magic with Spiritualist currents.

This is the core of Hockley's instructions for crystal and mirror scrying, presented as direct revelations from his 'C.A. the Guardian Spirit of my Mirror.' It begins by establishing the 'Urim and Thummim' as the ancient, semi-divine origin of scrying. The text then differentiates between types of spirits (Atmospheric, Guardian, High Order Angels) and methods of interaction. It provides clear, step-by-step guidance for practitioners, covering the ethical prerequisites, the dedication of the scrying instrument, the precise 'Call' for summoning spirits, and the crucial 'Exorcism' and 'Dismissal' rituals to ensure safety and prevent negative influences. This section forms the operational manual of Hockley's system.

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix: Hockley's Invocation of the Crowned Angel
structure_content.summary: This appendix offers a rare, detailed record of a specific scrying séance conducted by Frederick Hockley with his seer, Mrs. C. Lea, on October 7, 1859. It vividly illustrates the practical application of Hockley's system, including the instantaneous appearance of the Crowned Angel (C.A.) and a subsequent conversation with the spirit of Emma Leigh. The record documents the setup (involving two mirrors), the dialogue with the spirits, the emotional and physical effects on the seer, and the complex interplay between the magician, the seer, and the invoked entities. This section provides invaluable empirical evidence of Hockley's practices and the nature of spirit communication within his framework.

key_concepts.definition: The practice of divination and spirit communication using crystals, mirrors, or other transparent objects. Hockley's system defines it as the most effective means for obtaining 'Spiritual knowledge' and contacting high-order spirits.

Presented as the ancient, semi-divine origin of all scrying methods, specifically linked to crystals and mirrors for seeing 'Guardian Spirits and angels of the highest degree'. It implies a method of divine revelation and communication.

A high-order spirit specifically associated with the scrying instrument (crystal or mirror) and the practitioner. It acts as a guide, protector, and facilitator for visions and communication with other spirits, requiring dedication and proper ritual interaction.

An individual (like Mrs. Lea or Emma Leigh) who possesses the 'gift of second-sight' and can perceive visions or spirits within the crystal or mirror, often acting as an intermediary for the magician.

Spirits of a lower order or degree, including dead persons, undeveloped spirits, wandering spirits, and evil spirits. They are seen as residing in their own 'Sphere' and are viewed 'through' the scrying instrument as if through a window, rather than appearing directly in it like higher spirits.

The specific invocation ritual used to summon a spirit (e.g., Guardian Spirit or another entity) to appear in the crystal or mirror. It involves addressing 'the Almighty God' and humbly beseeching the desired spirit by name (N), to be repeated three times or mentally until appearance.

A ritual adjunct to the Call, used to command any unwanted or inappropriate spirit ('if he be not N whom I have called') to instantly disappear, ensuring the purity of the communication channel. This is used specifically for Spirits or Angels.

The concluding ritual, 'invariably used at the close of every action when Spirits have been called,' to release all spirits from the crystal/mirror and ensure the instrument is not 'spoiled.' It aims to maintain peace between the practitioner and the spirits, and is said three times.

practical_system.description: Hockley's system is a form of ceremonial scrying designed for communicating with various spirits, from 'Atmospheric Spirits' (including the deceased) to 'Guardian Spirits' and 'angels of the highest degree,' primarily through consecrated crystals and mirrors. The system is predicated on purity of intention, fervent dedication to God, and a structured ritual process to ensure safe and effective interaction, thereby preventing interference from 'Evil' influences. It posits the 'Urim and Thummim' as the purest and most efficacious form of divination, forming the philosophical bedrock of his method.
tools: **Crystal**: A 'good clear stone' is the initial and foundational tool, requiring consecration and purity.
**Mirror**: Considered 'very great deal the best' for experienced practitioners, offering 'large and life-like' visions and facilitating closer contact with spirits than crystals.

**Seer**: An indispensable intermediary, typically an individual with the 'gift of second-sight' who gazes into the scrying instrument and verbally relays the visions and communications from the spirits to the magician. This role is central to the operative success of the system.
rituals: **Preparation**: Procure a 'good clear stone' (crystal) or mirror 'that no Spirit has been called in' (i.e., unsullied by previous magical work).

**Dedication**: Dedicate the instrument with a 'fervent prayer to God,' ensuring its use is for 'no bad purpose,' acknowledging that while not exclusively for 'good,' it must avoid malevolent intentions.

**Invocation (The Call)**: The central summoning ritual: 'In the name of the Almighty God in whom we live and move and have our being, I humbly beseech the Spirit of this Crystal or mirror, to appear therein. Then say N__ be pleased to appear.' This is repeated three times or mentally until the spirit manifests. For specific visions or persons, the request is adjusted accordingly, often including 'if convenient and agreeable.'
**First Meeting Protocol**: Interactions with a newly invoked Guardian Spirit should be limited to 'half an hour' during the initial session.
**Subsequent Invocations**: For the Guardian Spirit, an 'exorcism him 3 times earnestly' precedes questions. If the spirit does not vanish after this, it can be reliably trusted.

**Exorcism**: 'In the name of the Almighty God in whom we live and move and have our being, I adjure the Spirit now appearing in this Crystal if he be not N whom I have called instantly to disappear.' This specific exorcism is reserved for Spirits or Angels only, not for Atmospheric Spirits or living persons.

**Dismissal**: The essential closing ritual: 'In the name of the Almighty God in whom we live and move and have our being I dismiss from this crystal (and from all my M[irror]s & C[rysta]ls) all spirits that may have appeared therein and may the peace of God be between them and us for Ever.' This must be 'invariably used at the close of every action,' as failure to do so risks 'spoiling' the instruments and causing the Guardian Spirit to 'desert them.' Exorcisms and Dismissals are both to be said three times; a single discharge suffices if multiple spirits have been called.

**Ethical Conduct**: The practitioner must adhere to 'Truth and good intentions,' specifically avoiding the use of the system for 'gaining of money,' as such actions lead to 'lamentable' consequences.

relevant_quotes.text: THE Urim and Thummim was the first means of divining by the Crystal, from this all other modes of divining arose, and gave man a desire to obtain knowledge unknown to others. As mankind increased in knowledge it became more frequently used; and is the best means by which Spiritual knowledge can be obtained. Its origin was semi-divine

The Spirits do not actually appear in that nor the atmospheric Spirits but you look thro that, look in at and converse with them while moving thro their own Sphere. It is in the same way that you make a window in a house to look into the street, you still stay in your room, but if you wish to converse with any one in the street, you would speak and common courtesy would oblige them to answer. That is the way with Atmospheric Spirits.
Guardian Spirits and angels of the highest degree are only seen in the Urim and Thummim the Crystal or the Mirror.

Having first procured a good clear stone one that no Spirit has been called in, and supposing he could not see himself-a seer. He must determine to use it for no bad purpose. ... he should first dedicate it with a fervent prayer to God.

Without fail at the close of every action when Spirits have been called, whether the seer has been able to see them or not, this dismissal must be invariably used or your Crystals and Mirrors will be quite spoiled and their G[uardian]. S[pirit]. desert them.

critical_analysis.relevance: This manuscript is highly relevant to the study of Western Esotericism, particularly 19th-century occultism and Spiritualism. It provides a rare, firsthand account of a structured scrying system practiced by Frederick Hockley, a prominent figure in Victorian magic. It effectively bridges the gap between traditional grimoire magic and emerging Spiritualist practices, demonstrating how classical angelic invocation was adapted and simplified for a new era. The inclusion of personal séance records in the appendix offers invaluable insight into the lived experience of these practices, the challenges of spirit communication, and the ethical/personal dilemmas faced by practitioners. It also sheds light on the dynamic interplay between the magician, the seer, and the spirits, emphasizing the unique and central role of the Guardian Spirit.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The immediate target audience for the original manuscript was Barbara Honywood, a fellow Spiritualist interested in visionary experience but lacking the personal ability to scry. For the published edition, the target audience is diverse, including academic researchers in the history of esotericism and Spiritualism, practitioners of ceremonial magic interested in historical methods, and occultists seeking to understand a specific lineage of scrying practice. It serves as both a primary historical document and a practical guide for those seeking to engage in spirit communication through crystals and mirrors, offering a unique blend of philosophical foundation and operative instruction.
